Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 52137-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2018 
Railway Sector Development in Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation Countries 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

ABBREVIATIONS 
ADB  – Asian Development Bank
ARTCF  – United Kingdom Fund for Asia Regional Trade and Connectivity
CAREC  – Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation
CWRD  – Central and West Asia Department
PRC  – People’s Republic of China
PRCF  – People's Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional
Cooperation Fund
RWG  – Railway Working Group
TA  – technical assistance
NOTE 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

Director General  Werner E. Liepach, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD)

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 19102018160547701883 Generated Date: 05-Nov-2018 14:20:03 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  accelerate  the  sound 
development of the railway subsector in Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 
countries1 through railway transport market research, project identification and preparation, 
knowledge sharing, and capacity development. 
 
2.  The  TA  aligns  with  Strategy  2030  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB);  ADB’s 
Operational  Plan  for  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration,  2016–2020;  the  CAREC  2030 
strategy; the CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy 2020; and the CAREC railway 
strategy, 2017–2030.2 It also complements other regional cooperation programs, such as the Belt 
and Road Initiative of the People’s Republic of China (PRC), the Transport Corridor Europe–
Caucasus–Asia program supported by the European Union, the Trans-Asian Railway supported 
by the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, and the Lapis 
Lazuli Corridor agreement.3 The TA supports regional and interregional trade and cooperation 
and promotes ADB as a prime development partner in the railway subsector in Central and West 
Asia, aiming for strong, long-term engagement with CAREC member countries.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Transport remains the primary vehicle for regional cooperation and integration in CAREC 
countries. Aiming to transform CAREC countries from landlocked to land-linked, the CAREC 
Program supports the expansion of trade and the improvement of economic development by more 
closely connecting the CAREC region with its larger and rapidly growing neighbors. Central Asia 
has great potential to benefit from growing Eurasian transit traffic and the intraregional trade. The 
development of an effective, efficient, sustainable, safe, and user-friendly multimodal corridor 
network is the primary means of achieving this goal. Transport has therefore remained the largest 
sector of activity in the 17-year history of the CAREC Program, accounting for more than 80% of 
investments totaling $25 billion. 
 
4.  CAREC countries are increasing their emphasis on railways for regional connectivity. 
Transport activities are guided by the Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy 2020 approved 
by CAREC countries in 2013, which recognized the need for balanced development of different 
modes. Particular emphasis was placed on developing railway transport, given its dominant role 
in external trade and transit. In many CAREC countries, railways receive more attention and 
increased financial support since improved railway connectivity facilitates trade and can have a 
competitive advantage in terms of transport time and cost over other modes of transport. 
 
5.  Subsequently, CAREC countries formulated the CAREC railway strategy, 2017–2030 to 
serve as a guiding document for the sound, long-term development of CAREC railways. The 
                                                
1  Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Pakistan, the People's Republic of 
China (Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region and Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region), Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and 
Uzbekistan. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila; ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting Connectivity, 
Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila; ADB. 2017. CAREC 
2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila; ADB. 2014. CAREC Transport and 
Trade Facilitation Strategy 2020. Manila; and ADB. 2016. Unlocking the Potential of Railways: A Railway Strategy 
for CAREC, 2017–2030. Manila. 
3  Signed in November 2017 between Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Turkey, and Turkmenistan. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 31 October 2018.

2 
strategy was formulated by the Railway Working Group (RWG),5 which consists of representatives 
of railway agencies from CAREC countries, and was endorsed at the 15th CAREC Ministerial 
Conference on 26 October 2016. The strategy is intended to equip the region’s railways to better 
capture evolving trade flows and contribute to regional development. It formulates a number of 
priorities for the following three primary efforts: develop effective rail infrastructure, develop robust 
commercial capabilities, and improve legal and regulatory frameworks.6 Designated rail corridors 
have been conceived by the RWG to (i) develop the national rail systems and (ii) benefit from 
regional transport connections.7 
 
6.  Despite  their  importance,  railways  in  the  CAREC  region  often  struggle  to  remain 
competitive.  Since  rail  networks  have  a  long  life,  existing  network  configurations  do  not 
necessarily match new traffic patterns; many railways in the region struggle to adapt to these 
changing  conditions.  Besides  gaps  in  effective  railway  infrastructure,  the  lack  of  robust 
commercial capabilities and inadequate legal and regulatory frameworks have caused railway 
market shares to decline, and most railways are not fully able to capture available trade flows. An 
increasing amount of freight traffic is carried by roads rather than rail, costing CAREC economies 
more in the form of traffic congestion, road crashes, and road asset deterioration. As a result, 
interregional and intraregional trade is subjected to high transportation costs and bottlenecks. 
 
7.  Further  development  of  railways  requires  ways  to  prioritize  investments,  structure 
financing, and improve institutions. A regional railway system that has been improved through 
infrastructure investments and policy measures will enhance access to regional and international 
markets and help increase economic growth and social welfare. 
 
8.  New investments are needed to maintain and improve the competitiveness of railways, 
but it is difficult to attract commercial financing because railways are bulky, long term, and risky 
in nature. There is the continued need to seek financing and funding from the government and 
international financial institutions, with further consideration on how such public funds can attract 
private financing. Furthermore, CAREC countries lack an adequate regional traffic model that is 
needed to identify the most promising rail transport routes and to prioritize investments in rail 
infrastructure. 
 
9.  The institutional and commercial changes needed to improve the financial sustainability 
of railway organizations are difficult to implement and are time-consuming, requiring systematic 
injection of knowledge and continued capacity building support. CAREC railways need to engage 
in a process of commercialization and reform to become efficient, customer-oriented transport 
operators, making investments economically viable. While the approach and pace of reform will 
differ among CAREC railway organizations, there is valuable knowledge to share in common 
areas,  such  as  financial  restructuring,  corporatization,  marketing,  asset  management, 
interoperability, and railway safety. 
 
10.  At the 17th Meeting of the CAREC Transport Sector Coordinating Committee held on 18–
20 April 2018 in Istanbul, Turkey, CAREC member countries expressed particular interest in 
regional TA that would help the RWG address common challenges. 
 
                                                
5  The RWG was set up by a decision of the 14th Transport Sector Coordinating Committee in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, 
in April 2015. 
6  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Strategy: Vision, Approach, and Priorities (accessible from the list of 
linked documents in Appendix 3). 
7  ADB. 2014. CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy 2020. Manila.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: railway transport that is quick, efficient, 
accessible for customers, easy to use throughout the region, and the mode of choice for trade 
achieved.8 The TA will have the following outcome: railway investments in CAREC countries 
prioritized to match market opportunities and backed by sector reforms.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Subregional rail traffic model developed. Under this output, ADB will develop 
a regional transport model that will indicate main traffic flows by origin and destination and type 
of cargo. The model will identify the cargo flows most suitable for rail transport, such as bulk goods 
and container transport, as well as crucial intermodal connections and border-crossing points. 
The analysis of the transport flows will include an assessment of the sustainability of the volumes 
and routes. Where relevant to define viability, passenger transport will be addressed as well. 
Based on this assessment, priority projects for the completion of missing rail links and other critical 
investments (such as electrification, rolling stock, and terminals) will be identified and proposed 
for inclusion in national railway investment plans. The model will help demonstrate to CAREC 
countries the need for concerted investment planning to reap benefits from regional transport. 
The model will be made publicly available through the CAREC website. Further, the aim is to link 
the CAREC transport model with the transport corridor data collected for the Greater Mekong 
Subregion to gradually develop an Asia-wide rail transport database.10  
 
13.  Output 2: Project preparation facility established. To help CAREC countries formulate 
bankable investment projects, the TA will facilitate swift mobilization of expertise to screen project 
options, perform pre-feasibility studies or validate existing pre-feasibility or feasibility studies, and 
support the prioritization and initial conceptualization of investments. This will also allow ADB and 
other CAREC development partners to scope out their potential support before full-fledged project 
preparation. Future RWG meetings will be used to receive project ideas in line with the CAREC 
railway strategy that may find sufficient government commitment to be implemented under the 
CAREC Program. The TA team will, in consultation with the RWG, select project suggestions 
based on project size and complexity, regional impact, interest to include the project in the 
countries’ lending programs, feasibility to perform a quick assessment, and relative urgency. The 
TA will allow screening of such project ideas on their economic and technical viability at relatively 
short notice. 
 
14.  Output 3: Knowledge products completed. The TA will develop knowledge products 
and conduct events in common areas of interest in sector reform and commercialization, such as 
state-owned enterprise restructuring, financial restructuring, asset management, tariff regulation, 
border-crossing policies, and interoperability. Topics will be prioritized based on consultations to 
be done at the first RWG meeting under this TA. Development partners will be invited to join and 
contribute to related activities, strengthening coordination and dialogue in the region. 
 
15.  Output 4: Capacity of executing agencies in project preparation improved. The TA 
will facilitate activities to strengthen the capacity of railway agencies in key areas required for the 
                                                
8  ADB. 2016. Unlocking the Potential of Railways: A Railway Strategy for CAREC, 2017–2030. Manila. 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
10 ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance for Connecting the Railways of the Greater Mekong Subregion. Manila.

4 
development  of  bankable  projects,  such  as  procurement,  financial  and  economic  project 
evaluation, safeguards, and gender mainstreaming. Furthermore, the awareness and capacity of 
railway agencies will be strengthened in the application of less traditional financial instruments 
such  as  sector  loans  and  policy-based  loans.  Based  on  staffing,  procedures,  and  policy 
diagnostics of the railway agencies in the participating developing member countries, an agency-
specific set of actions and measures will be identified and supported under the TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund 
(PRCF)11 and (ii) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the United Kingdom Fund for 
Asia Regional Trade and Connectivity (ARTCF) under the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility, both to be administered by ADB. The PRCF will predominantly 
finance consulting services, while ARTCF funds will particularly be used for costs related to events 
and publications.12 The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, with the Transport and Communications 
Division of the Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) responsible for managing the TA. 
Staff of the East Asia Department will be consulted for coordination with its developing member 
countries.  TA  activities  will  also  be  aligned  with  activities  of  the  Transport  Sector  Group 
coordinated by ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department. This will help 
to promote interregional cooperation, where the TA’s activities can be linked to initiatives of the 
Greater Mekong Subregion and the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation program. The 
Transport Sector Group will be kept informed on the progress and outputs achieved under this 
TA to ensure complementarity. 
 
18.  The primary vehicle for TA implementation will be the RWG. Representatives of each 
CAREC country and development partner to the RWG will be invited to provide inputs and 
feedback on TA activities and outputs. RWG meetings will be held at least once a year to agree 
on key actions and monitor progress against them. Key decisions by the RWG will be put forward 
to the CAREC Transport Sector Coordinating Committee, as the sector governing body under the 
CAREC Program, for endorsement and further guidance. The TA will financially support the 
conduct of RWG, Transport Sector Coordinating Committee and other associated events in 
support of the TA outputs and outcome. The Transport and Communications Division of the 
CWRD being part of the CAREC Secretariat will also be responsible for the organization  of 
meetings and events in cooperation with the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division of the CWRD. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented in coordination with development partners including but not 
limited to the CAREC Institute, the International Union of Railways, the Organisation for Co-
                                                
11 The PRCF was originally named the People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund 
in the 2005 Board paper. 
12 The PRCF will finance expenses related to the TA and other eligible initiatives agreed by the PRC and ADB, including 
consulting services, training, conferences, and workshops. The PRCF may also finance small-scale civil works and 
other related expenses. The ARTCF will finance TA expenses in the form of consulting services, training events, 
conferences and workshops, and related activities. The grant can be used to support staff resources related to 
ARTCF management in the form of sponsored staff and staff consultants as necessary.

5 
operation between Railways, and the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia 
and the Pacific. 
 
20.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  November 2018–December 2022 
Executing agency  ADB 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Individual selection  International expertise  $1,075,000 
(30 person-months) 
Individual selection  National expertise (22  $200,000 
person-months) 
Disbursement  The technical assistance resources will be disbursed following 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank. 
Source: ADB. 
 
21.  Consulting services. Individual international and national consultants will be hired on an 
intermittent  basis  on  output-based  contracts  where  appropriate.  Resource  persons  with 
specialized knowledge in key areas of the TA’s scope will also be hired on basis of need. ADB 
will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.13 
 
22.  Social media and websites. The TA team will clearly indicate in publications, training 
programs, conferences, and workshops financed by the PRCF and ARTCF that such activities 
received funding from the governments of the PRC and the United Kingdom. Photo materials and 
news briefs will be made during events for use by local print and electronic media. The names 
and logos of the financiers will be used in publications, reports, and event and promotion 
materials. Regular updates will be provided to feed relevant websites. 
 
23.  Cofinancier requirements. Semiannual progress reports will be provided to the PRCF 
and ARTCF, including an overview of expenditures. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance (TA) not exceeding the 
equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the People's Republic of China 
Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund and (ii) ADB administering TA not exceeding 
the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the United Kingdom Fund for Asia 
Regional Trade and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing 
Partnership  Facility  for  Railway  Sector  Development  in  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
